The electric grid is undergoing a dramatic change.
Increasing adoption of renewables,
and storage at the bulk grid are increasing variability and flexibility.
Consumers are adopting electric vehicles,
smart appliances, storage, and solar,
enabling them to become prosumers who can
actively participate in wholesale and retail markets.
System operators, utilities, and aggregators are
able to access increasing amounts of real time data,
and they use it to plan,
monitor and operate the grid.
The digitization of the electric grid, leveraging the availability of massive data,
cheap Cloud computing, and rapidly evolving data science, and AI,
will result in a transformation of the ecosystem.
It will lead to the emergence of new market places,
pricing strategies, novel services, and
opportunities for increased automation and autonomy.
This radical transformation is taking the grid,
beyond the traditional concept of smart grids.
The aim of this course is to introduce you to
the modern electric grid and focus on major transformative technologies:
renewables, storage, prosumers, electric vehicles, and artificial intelligence.
Each topic is covered as a module and they connect to the basic way the grid works today.
After the class, you should be able to understand how the grid works,
how it's changing, and what is the role of key technologies and important opportunities.
This class offers a good background for engineers,
investors, and policy makers interested in this space,
to engage in activities such as developing new solutions,
identifying opportunities for innovation, and assessing impacts.
